entries.title: Carbon Footprint
entries.simpleText: The total amount of greenhouse gases a product creates from making it to throwing it away, measured in CO2.
entries.analogy: Like tracking how many miles your food traveled to reach your plate, but for pollution.

entries.title: Product Carbon Footprint (PCF)
entries.simpleText: The pollution created just from making a product in the factory, before it gets shipped anywhere.
entries.analogy: Like the ingredients that go into baking a cake, before you deliver it.

entries.title: Transport Carbon Footprint (TCF)
entries.simpleText: The pollution created from shipping a product from the factory to where it's sold or used.
entries.analogy: Like the gas used by a delivery truck bringing a package to your house.

entries.title: Use Phase Carbon Footprint (UCF)
entries.simpleText: The pollution created while you actually use a product over its lifetime, like electricity it consumes.
entries.analogy: Like the electricity your TV uses every time you watch it.

entries.title: End-of-Life Carbon Footprint
entries.simpleText: The pollution created when a product is recycled, reused, or thrown away at the end of its life.
entries.analogy: Like the energy needed to crush a can at the recycling center.

entries.title: CO2 Equivalent (CO2eq)
entries.simpleText: A way to measure all greenhouse gases using carbon dioxide as a common unit, like converting currencies.
entries.analogy: Like converting euros to dollars so you can compare prices from different countries.

entries.title: Recyclability
entries.simpleText: How much of a product can be turned into new materials instead of ending up in a landfill.
entries.analogy: Like melting down old LEGO bricks to make new ones instead of throwing them away.

entries.title: Recycled Content
entries.simpleText: The percentage of a product that was made from materials that were previously used in other products.
entries.analogy: Like a notebook made from old newspapers instead of fresh trees.

entries.title: Circular Economy
entries.simpleText: A system where products are designed to be reused, repaired, and recycled instead of thrown away.
entries.analogy: Like a library where books are shared and passed around instead of everyone buying and throwing away their own.

entries.title: Water Footprint
entries.simpleText: The total amount of fresh water used to make a product, from growing materials to manufacturing.
entries.analogy: Like counting every drop of water needed to grow cotton and dye it to make your t-shirt.

entries.title: Energy Efficiency Class
entries.simpleText: A letter grade (A to G) showing how much electricity a product uses, where A is best and G is worst.
entries.analogy: Like report card grades, but for how much electricity something wastes.

entries.title: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA)
entries.simpleText: A complete study of a product's environmental impact from raw materials to disposal.
entries.analogy: Like a biography of a product's environmental story from birth to death.

entries.title: Life Cycle Phase
entries.simpleText: A specific stage in a product's life: making it, transporting it, using it, or disposing of it.
entries.analogy: Like the chapters in a product's life story: childhood, adulthood, and retirement.

entries.title: State of Health (SoH)
entries.simpleText: A percentage showing how much life is left in a battery compared to when it was new.
entries.analogy: Like a fitness score for your battery - 100% means brand new, 80% means it's getting tired.

entries.title: Battery Capacity
entries.simpleText: How much energy a battery can store, measured in kilowatt-hours, like a fuel tank size.
entries.analogy: Like the size of a water bottle - bigger capacity means it holds more.

entries.title: Cycle Count
entries.simpleText: The number of times a battery has been fully charged and discharged over its lifetime.
entries.analogy: Like counting how many times you've filled up your car's gas tank.

entries.title: Battery Impedance
entries.simpleText: How much a battery resists the flow of electricity - higher means the battery is wearing out.
entries.analogy: Like how a clogged pipe makes water flow slower; old batteries resist electricity flow.

entries.title: Battery Degradation
entries.simpleText: The gradual loss of a battery's ability to hold a charge over time and use.
entries.analogy: Like how a sponge slowly loses its ability to hold water after many uses.

entries.title: Kilowatt-Hour (kWh)
entries.simpleText: A unit of energy that measures how much power is used over one hour.
entries.analogy: If a 1000-watt microwave runs for one hour, that's 1 kWh - like fuel for your appliances.

entries.title: Digital Product Passport (DPP)
entries.simpleText: An electronic ID card for products that stores information about where they came from and how to recycle them.
entries.analogy: Like a passport for your phone that tells its complete life story.

entries.title: ESPR (Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation)
entries.simpleText: An EU law requiring products to be designed for repair, reuse, and recycling.
entries.analogy: Like school rules that say products must be built to last and be recyclable.

entries.title: Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR)
entries.simpleText: A rule that makes companies responsible for their products even after you buy them, including recycling.
entries.analogy: Like if a restaurant had to clean up trash from all the takeout containers they give out.

entries.title: Due Diligence
entries.simpleText: The careful checking companies must do to make sure their products are made ethically and legally.
entries.analogy: Like doing your homework to make sure the ingredients in your lunchbox came from fair sources.

entries.title: Supply Chain
entries.simpleText: All the steps and companies involved in making a product, from raw materials to the store shelf.
entries.analogy: Like a relay race where each runner passes materials to the next until the product reaches you.

entries.title: Traceability
entries.simpleText: The ability to track every step of how a product was made and where its parts came from.
entries.analogy: Like following breadcrumbs back through a forest to see exactly where you started.

entries.title: Asset Administration Shell (AAS)
entries.simpleText: A digital twin standard that stores all information about a physical product in a structured way.
entries.analogy: Like a detailed digital profile page for a product that any computer can read.

entries.title: Submodel
entries.simpleText: A specific category of information about a product, like its nameplate, documentation, or carbon data.
entries.analogy: Like different chapters in a product's instruction manual - one for specs, one for safety, etc.

entries.title: Semantic ID
entries.simpleText: A unique web address that defines exactly what a piece of data means, so all computers understand it the same way.
entries.analogy: Like a dictionary definition that everyone agrees on, so 'apple' always means the fruit.

entries.title: IDTA (Industrial Digital Twin Association)
entries.simpleText: The organization that creates standards for digital twins so different companies can share product data.
entries.analogy: Like the group that decided what size paper and envelopes should be so mail works everywhere.

entries.title: Digital Nameplate
entries.simpleText: Electronic version of the metal plate on machines showing manufacturer, model, and serial number.
entries.analogy: Like the sticker on your laptop that shows who made it and its serial number, but digital.

entries.title: Serial Number
entries.simpleText: A unique code that identifies one specific product out of all the identical ones made.
entries.analogy: Like your social security number, but for a product - no two are the same.

entries.title: Batch Number
entries.simpleText: A code identifying a group of products made together at the same time in the same way.
entries.analogy: Like cookies from the same tray in the oven - they all share the same batch number.

entries.title: Firmware
entries.simpleText: The permanent software built into a device that controls how it works at the most basic level.
entries.analogy: Like the instincts a device is born with - you can update it, but it's always there.

entries.title: Software Version
entries.simpleText: A number showing which update of a program is installed, like 2.0 being newer than 1.0.
entries.analogy: Like edition numbers on textbooks - version 2.0 has newer content than version 1.0.

entries.title: QR Code
entries.simpleText: A square barcode pattern that phones can scan to instantly open websites or product information.
entries.analogy: Like a secret door that opens when you point your phone camera at it.

entries.title: Third-Party Verification
entries.simpleText: When an independent company checks that environmental claims are true and accurate.
entries.analogy: Like having a referee check the score instead of trusting the players.

entries.title: Certification
entries.simpleText: An official document proving a product meets certain standards or requirements.
entries.analogy: Like a diploma that proves the product graduated from quality school.

entries.title: Compliance
entries.simpleText: Following all the rules and laws that apply to how products are made and sold.
entries.analogy: Like following traffic rules - you have to do it to legally drive on the road.

entries.title: Greenhouse Gas (GHG)
entries.simpleText: Gases like CO2 that trap heat in the atmosphere and contribute to climate change.
entries.analogy: Like a blanket around Earth that keeps getting thicker and warmer.

entries.title: Cradle-to-Gate
entries.simpleText: Measuring environmental impact from raw materials until the product leaves the factory.
entries.analogy: Like tracking a pizza's journey from the farm to when it leaves the restaurant kitchen.

entries.title: Cradle-to-Grave
entries.simpleText: Measuring environmental impact from raw materials through the entire product life until disposal.
entries.analogy: Like tracking a pizza from the farm all the way to when you throw away the box.

entries.title: End of Life
entries.simpleText: The stage when a product is no longer used and needs to be recycled, reused, or disposed of.
entries.analogy: Like retirement for products - what happens after their working days are over.

entries.title: Transport Mode
entries.simpleText: How a product gets shipped: by truck, train, ship, or airplane, each with different pollution levels.
entries.analogy: Like choosing between walking, biking, or driving - each has a different environmental cost.

entries.title: Energy Consumption
entries.simpleText: How much electricity or fuel a product uses while operating.
entries.analogy: Like how much food you eat - some products are hungry for energy, others barely snack.

entries.title: Carbon Intensity
entries.simpleText: How much CO2 is produced for each unit of energy used, varies by power source.
entries.analogy: Like comparing how much smoke comes from burning wood versus natural gas.

entries.title: Material Composition
entries.simpleText: A list of all the materials used to make a product and how much of each.
entries.analogy: Like a recipe showing all ingredients in a product: 50% steel, 30% plastic, 20% copper.

entries.title: Hazardous Substances
entries.simpleText: Dangerous chemicals in products that can harm health or the environment if not handled properly.
entries.analogy: Like warning labels on cleaning products - some ingredients need special care.

entries.title: RoHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances)
entries.simpleText: An EU rule limiting dangerous chemicals like lead and mercury in electronics.
entries.analogy: Like food safety rules that ban certain additives from your snacks.

entries.title: WEEE (Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment)
entries.simpleText: EU rules for how old electronics must be collected and recycled properly.
entries.analogy: Like special trash pickup rules for electronics so they don't end up polluting landfills.

entries.title: CE Marking
entries.simpleText: A symbol showing a product meets EU safety, health, and environmental requirements.
entries.analogy: Like a stamp of approval saying 'this product is safe to sell in Europe'.

entries.title: Digital Twin
entries.simpleText: A virtual copy of a physical product that contains all its information and can be updated in real-time.
entries.analogy: Like a video game character that perfectly mirrors a real person's movements.

entries.title: Interoperability
entries.simpleText: The ability of different computer systems and products to work together and share information.
entries.analogy: Like LEGO bricks - they all fit together no matter which set they came from.

entries.title: API (Application Programming Interface)
entries.simpleText: A set of rules that lets different software programs talk to each other and share data.
entries.analogy: Like a restaurant menu - it tells you what you can order and how to ask for it.

entries.title: Expected Lifetime
entries.simpleText: How long a product is designed to work properly before it wears out or needs replacement.
entries.analogy: Like the 'best before' date on products, but for how long they'll keep working.

entries.title: Durability
entries.simpleText: How well a product holds up over time and resists breaking or wearing out.
entries.analogy: Like how some jeans last years while others get holes after a few months.

entries.title: Repairability
entries.simpleText: How easy it is to fix a product when something breaks instead of throwing it away.
entries.analogy: Like being able to change a bike tire yourself versus needing a special shop.

entries.title: Spare Parts Availability
entries.simpleText: Whether replacement parts can be bought to fix a product instead of replacing the whole thing.
entries.analogy: Like being able to buy a new phone screen instead of a whole new phone.
